title: Ross Tokely
text:
Ross Tokely (born 8 March 1979) is a Scottish professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and coach who plays for <a href="St%20Duthus%20F.C.">St. Duthus FC</a> in the <a href="North%20Caledonian%20Football%20Association">North Caledonian League</a>. Tokely previously played for <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness Caledonian Thistle</a>, <a href="Ross%20County%20F.C.">Ross County</a> and <a href="Brora%20Rangers%20F.C.">Brora Rangers</a> as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">right-back.</a>
Tokely joined Inverness from <a href="Highland%20Football%20League">Highland League</a> club <a href="Huntly%20F.C.">Huntly</a> in 1996 and remained at the club until June 2012, for a total of 16 seasons at the <a href="Inverness">Inverness</a> club. Tokely was ICT's longest serving player and currently holds their appearance record. He also holds the distinction of having played and scored in every division of <a href="Scottish%20football%20pyramid">Scottish league football</a>, from <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20Third%20Division">Third Division</a> to the <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">SPL</a>, for Inverness.
Playing career.
Inverness.
Tokely was born in <a href="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a>. He was signed to <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness Caledonian Thistle</a> by manager Steve Paterson and made his first appearance in the side that won the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20Third%20Division">Third Division</a> title in <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20in%20Scottish%20football">1997</a>. Tokely gradually established himself in the side, usually playing at right back, although he has sometimes played in central defence or as a <a href="Midfielder%20%28association%20football%29">holding midfielder</a>.
Tokely retained his place in the team as Inverness progressed through the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20Third%20Division">Third Division</a> and <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> to the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a>.
Tokely also had more positive successes during this period, notably a fantastic goal against his boyhood heroes <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.">Hearts</a> in the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20Scottish%20Cup">2002</a> <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a>. Tokely hit a 20-yard shot into the top corner at <a href="Tynecastle%20Stadium">Tynecastle</a> as Inverness defeated another SPL club in the cup, having won 3–1 at <a href="Celtic%20Park">Celtic Park</a> in <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20Scottish%20Cup">2000</a>. Tokely also scored the winning <a href="Penalty%20kick%20%28association%20football%29">penalty</a> in a <a href="Penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">shoot-out</a> against <a href="Dunfermline%20Athletic%20F.C.">Dunfermline Athletic</a> in the following <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Scottish%20League%20Cup">season</a>'s <a href="Scottish%20League%20Cup">League Cup</a>.
Tokely was part of the squad that won promotion to the <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">SPL</a> in <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20in%20Scottish%20football">2004</a>, by winning the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> title. As Inverness moved into the SPL, he retained his spot in the side, being awarded the number 2 jersey. After 10 years of service to the club, Tokely was awarded a <a href="testimonial%20match">testimonial match</a> against <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a>.
Throughout their five-year stint in the top league, Tokely was an established player in the side. His longest spell out of the team came in 2007, when he missed a month of first team action after being sent off for an off the ball punch on <a href="Motherwell%20F.C.">Motherwell</a> player <a href="Steven%20McGarry">Steven McGarry</a>. As the Highland club unsuccessfully battled against relegation in <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Scottish%20Premier%20League">2009</a>, manager <a href="Terry%20Butcher">Terry Butcher</a> joked that he wanted his side to achieve more league points than Tokley's total of disciplinary points. Tokely racked up further disciplinary points as he was sent off for a professional foul on the final day of the season against <a href="Falkirk%20F.C.">Falkirk</a>. Inverness went on to lose the decisive match 1–0, and were consequently relegated.
Nonetheless, Tokely retained his place in the Inverness side after their drop back down to the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a>, helping the club gain promotion straight back to the SPL in <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Scottish%20First%20Division">2010</a>. He was made <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a> of the team for his 500th appearance for Inverness, a 1–0 win against <a href="Airdrie%20United%20F.C.">Airdrie United</a>. Tokely agreed a new contract with Inverness in June 2010, despite receiving offers from overseas. In May 2012, he rejected a contract offer from Inverness and ended his 16-year career with the club.
Ross County.
On 7 June 2012, Tokely signed for <a href="Ross%20County%20F.C.">Ross County</a> on a one-year contract.
Brora Rangers.
Tokely joined <a href="Brora%20Rangers%20F.C.">Brora Rangers</a> as a player/coach in January 2013. On Saturday 5 October Brora drew 1–1 with league rivals <a href="Cove%20Rangers%20F.C.">Cove Rangers</a>, but went on to beat them 3–0 away from home in the <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a>, flying high in the Highland League, Brora were favourites to beat <a href="Clyde%20F.C.">Clyde</a> in the 2nd round but lost 2–1 at <a href="Broadwood%20Stadium">Broadwood</a>.
In 2013–14 Brora won the <a href="Highland%20Football%20League">Highland League</a> for the first time in their history - by twenty-clear-points. They also won the <a href="North%20of%20Scotland%20Cup">North Of Scotland Cup</a> for the fourth time when they beat <a href="Elgin%20City%20F.C.">Elgin City</a> in the 2014–15 final.
On 26 July 2014, Brora knocked <a href="Stenhousemuir%20F.C.">Stenhousemuir</a> out of the <a href="Scottish%20Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> after extra-time 3–1, Alex Sutherland hat-trick, to be beaten by <a href="East%20Fife%20F.C.">East Fife</a> in the second round 3–1.
St Duthus.
Midway through the 2018–19 season, Tokely made a return to senior football when he joined Tain based <a href="North%20Caledonian%20Football%20League">North Caledonian League</a> club <a href="St%20Duthus%20F.C.">St Duthus</a>.
Coaching career.
Tokely was appointed Brora Rangers manager in December 2016. Brora knocked SPFL clubs <a href="Stranraer%20F.C.">Stranraer</a> and <a href="East%20Fife%20F.C.">East Fife</a> out of the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Scottish%20Cup">2017–18 Scottish Cup</a>, before eventually losing to Premiership club <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a> in the fifth round (last 16). They had poorer results in the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Highland%20Football%20League">2017–18 Highland Football League</a>, however, and Tokely left the club near the end of the season.
Tokely returned to Inverness to become their Youth Team coach.
Honours.
Inverness CT
Brora Rangers
St Duthus
